questions.answer_description: AWS S3 supports client side or server side encryption to encrypt all data at rest. The server side encryption can either have the S3 supplied AES-256 encryption key or the user can send the key along with each API call to supply his own encryption key. Amazon S3 never stores the user's encryption key. The user has to supply it for each encryption or decryption call.

choices.D: The admin should send the keys and encryption algorithm with each API call
choices.A: The admin should upload his secret key to the AWS console and let S3 decrypt the objects
choices.C: S3 does not support client supplied encryption keys for server side encryption
choices.B: The admin should use CLI or API to upload the encryption key to the S3 bucket. When making a call to the S3 API mention the encryption key URL in each request

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If the user wants to provide their own encryption keys for server-side encryption (SSE-C), they can achieve this by encrypting the data using their encryption key locally and then sending the encrypted data to Amazon S3 along with the necessary encryption information (keys and algorithm) in each API call. This way, the user maintains control over the encryption keys and the encryption process.
D. The admin should send the keys and encryption algorithm with each API call

Does Ans D says SSE -c or SDK Self managed key ?
https://cloudonaut.io/encrypting-sensitive-data-stored-on-s3/#:~:targetText=SSE%2DKMS%20is%20very%20similar,service%20and%20not%20by%20S3.&targetText=The%20default%20key%20policy%20allows,encrypt%2Fdecrypt%20using%20the%20CMK

questions.question_text:
A storage admin wants to encrypt all the objects stored in S3 using server side encryption. The user does not want to use the AES 256 encryption key provided by
S3. How can the user achieve this?
A user is trying to create a PIOPS EBS volume with 8 GB size and 200 IOPS. Will AWS create the volume?

choices.D: Yes, since PIOPS is higher than 100
choices.C: No, the EBS size is less than 10 GB
choices.A: Yes, since the ratio between EBS and IOPS is less than 30
choices.B: No, since the PIOPS and EBS size ratio is less than 30

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

This question is outdated. The IOPS ratio used to be 30:1 but it was increased to 50:1 in Aug-2016 according to this link: https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2016/08/amazon-ebs-delivers-improved-performance-and-price-reduction/#:~:text=We%20are%20pleased%20to%20announce,for%20a%20100%20GB%20volume.

With that said, the right answer at the moment this question was created is A.
Just tried this on the AWS console. D is the correct answer. It is totally possible in Aug 2020

Correct answer is D...
Minimum volume size is 4GB and minimum IOPS is 100. Log into the console and try this out yourself with the mentioned requirements, you will have an EBS volume with 8GB and 200 IOPS.

comments.content: Is it possible to provision more than 100 IOPS for volumes smaller than 10 GBs?
In that case, wouldn't the answer be A as only IOPS value cannot be a deciding factor; we will need the RATIO between IOPS and Volume size to be less than 30 for this to work, right?

discussion.content: C. No, the EBS size is less than 10 GB

questions.answer_description:
Amazon RDS performs maintenance on the DB instance during a user-definable maintenance window. The system may be offline or experience lower performance during that window. The only maintenance events that may require RDS to make the DB instance offline are:

Scaling compute operations -
Software patching. Required software patching is automatically scheduled only for patches that are security and durability related. Such patching occurs infrequently (typically once every few months) and seldom requires more than a fraction of the maintenance window.
questions.question_text: A user has scheduled the maintenance window of an RDS DB on Monday at 3 AM. Which of the below mentioned events may force to take the DB instance offline during the maintenance window?

choices.A: Launch the test and production instances in separate regions and allow region wise access to the group
choices.B: Define the IAM policy which allows access based on the instance ID
choices.C: Create an IAM policy with a condition which allows access to only small instances
choices.D: Define the tags on the test and production servers and add a condition to the IAM policy which allows access to specific tags

questions.answer_description: AWS Identity and Access Management is a web service which allows organizations to manage users and user permissions for various AWS services. The user can add conditions as a part of the IAM policies. The condition can be set on AWS Tags, Time, and Client IP as well as on various parameters. If the organization wants the user to access only specific instances he should define proper tags and add to the IAM policy condition. The sample policy is shown below.
questions.question_text: An organization has launched 5 instances: 2 for production and 3 for testing. The organization wants that one particular group of IAM users should only access the test instances and not the production ones. How can the organization set that as a part of the policy?

discussion.content: D. Define the tags on the test and production servers and add a condition to the IAM policy which allows

choices.C: Terminates the instance and updates the desired capacity and minimum size to 1
choices.B: Terminates the instance and updates the desired capacity to 1
choices.A: Terminates the instance and does not launch a new instance

questions.answer_description: The Auto Scaling command as-terminate-instance-in-auto-scaling-group <Instance ID> will terminate the specific instance ID. The user is required to specify the parameter as --decrement-desired-capacity. Then Auto Scaling will terminate the instance and decrease the desired capacity by 1. In this case since the minimum size is 2, Auto Scaling will not allow the desired capacity to go below 2. Thus, it will throw an error.
